conclusion: Objects A and B are being lowered toward stationary blocks C–F under the influence of gravity.
C (white) and D (brown) form a pair on the left side of the table.
E (yellow) and F (green) form a pair on the right side of the table.
A is positioned above the pair C–D, and B is positioned above the pair E–F.
As soon as A is released, gravity accelerates it downward until its bottom face meets the upper faces of C and D.
As soon as B is released, gravity accelerates it downward until its bottom face meets the upper faces of E and F.
Because each of C–F is rigid, A will come to rest on C–D and B will come to rest on E–F.
None of the four support blocks is expected to move appreciably (assuming their bases are stable and the friction with the tabletop is sufficient).
Object A ends up sitting on top of objects C and D.
Object B ends up sitting on top of objects E and F.
All six blocks are now in static equilibrium on the table.
A lands on C and D, B lands on E and F, and all six objects remain at rest.
